people assume that more data is better but with the new regulations this
approach leads to a lot more overhead in management so you really need to ask yourself about what you need why and

think about how you will start to surgically remove the data from the warehouse and files this is where things

finally is there a way for you to avoid the problem entirely if you have personal sensitive information stored
you need to be extremely careful with who can access that information and how to ensure that the data is protected if
you can avoid having to store sensitive information entirely you can create an

to that state where we minimize the risk associated with having personal and sensitive information in your analytics
pipeline well we think of it as three step process identify classify and
implement in the identify stage we're really talking about how to identify where P is starting with the source
system and then mapping that every downstream system earlier we talked
about how the data flows and during the identify stage you're looking at each field of P I to see if it or some
version of it exists in each of the downstream systems this is also where you need to examine your vendor
solutions to see if they may also be storing any of the PII data that may be working with that they may be working
with on your behalf once you've identified where all the data lives the next step is to classify that
information this is really about putting each type of data into a bucket first do
you need the data or not need it if you do need the data determine what you need and why you want to ask yourself whether
you actually need the raw data or if you can deal with partial data or if you can work with uniquely identified values
such as hashes or even GU its global being global unique ID ID values for
instance if you're working with phone numbers is the area code sufficient do you need to know the actual phone number
or could you just convert all numbers to a hash and perhaps store the hash along with the area code or other information
email address is another really common challenge can you uniquely hash the email address or use an ID value that
can later be used to access the original email address a pretty common use case for analytics is to generate lists of
users for marketing or other purposes for campaigns the analytics can actually
be performed without the email address itself but the call to action may require you to do something like a
rehydration to get the actual email address later on you can preserve
uniqueness without exposing the raw information and can run all types of analytics and get insight without
actually having the raw information and rehydration allows you to take those unique hashes or ID values from your
analytic system and then look them up whether it's back in the source system or somewhere else
to get the original values once the data has been identified and classified its
time to move on to the implementation this is where the hard work begins one
